content.description: Climb the middle of the slab. Start off center right, and climb up moving to the center and up the blankest part of the wall. There is thoughtful smearing most of the way. It is probably the most sustained climb here.
content.protection: TR off two bolts at the top.
content.location: There are probably a few ways to start this. I started just left of Smear Pressure. Look for two ripples down low which make an awkward starting hold, and move up to one a little out of reach to the left. I think I used the first part of the flake for my right hand as I moved to the center.

content.description: This climbs the far right side of the slab and follows a vague flake system part of the way. Near the top, trend left to the anchor. The crux is the first couple moves.
content.protection: TR off 2 bolts at the top.
content.location: Start on the far right just left if the tree. Smear up gastoning the flake with your left hand if you desire.

content.description: This climbs the left side of the slab staying close to the arete. A cruxy mantel and a blank section give way to fun featured climbing all the way to the top. Despite appearances, this might the easiest climb on the slab. You can can also forego the start be sneaking in from the left.
content.protection: TR off two bolts at the top.
content.location: On the far left of the slab but still on the main face, there is an ok starting hold for your left hand. Alternatively, you climb in from left starting around the main face.

content.description: Now that it is clean, this unassuming, previously lichen-covered slab has revealed some of the best routes outside Redrock on Cape Ann. There isn’t much by way of handholds, but the low angle and the featured rock keep the grades fairly moderate. If you are on the northshore and you like slabs, this is an excellent spot.There are two bolts at the top that work as an anchor for all three climbs. You have to do little easy scramble up the backside to gain the top.
